admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

abstracts.cdata!:
This project is rated as deficient,
            although an assessment during the continuing financial
            crisis must be read with caution. This project demonstrates
            the financial viability of small and medium-sized loans for
            agricultural enterprises at market rates of interest, and
            the potential for the commercial banks to play an increasing
            role in servicing this emerging market. At the same time,
            the present situation of very high real and nominal interest
            rates does not demonstrate that market rates are preferable
            to the subsidized climate. Bank performance is in part
            deficient and in part satisfactory while Borrower
            performance is satisfactory overall. Lessons learned
            specific to the project include: A project design relying
            upon case by case analyses of loans in certain subsectors or
            involving some commodities should be avoided if possible.
            The role of commercial banks in environmentally screening of
            projects submitted to them for financing would be better
            backed by a national code governing all their lending
            activities. The degree of convergence between government and
            Bank policies should not be overstated: the lesson here is
            that when full consensus is lacking, different views should
            be discussed and operational issues addressed. The principle
            of a government passing public debt to private interests and
            necessitating a government guarantee of private sector
            activities should be scrutinized. Any financial sector
            project should review the continuing soundness of the institutions.
